sn9.3:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā kassapagotto kosalesu viharati aññatarasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe.
sn9.3:1.1.eng: At one time Venerable Kassapagotta was staying in the land of the Kosalans in a certain forest grove.
sn9.3:1.1.comm: Kassapagotta appears also in AN 3.91, where he initially resents the training before repenting.

sn9.3:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā kassapagotto divāvihāragato aññataraṃ chetaṃ ovadati.
sn9.3:1.2.eng: Now at that time Venerable Kassapagotta, having withdrawn for his day’s meditation, tried to advise a nimrod.
sn9.3:1.2.comm: Cheta (variants ceṭa, ceta) is unsatisfactory. Commentary explains as “deer hunter”, apparently from the root chid (“cut, destroy”; cf. Sanskrit chettṛ). A “nimrod” is both a “hunter” and an “idiot”.

sn9.3:1.3.pli: Atha kho yā tasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe adhivatthā devatā āyasmantaṃ kassapagottaṃ saṃvejetukāmā yenāyasmā kassapagotto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ kassapagottaṃ gāthāhi ajjhabhāsi:
sn9.3:1.3.eng: Then the deity haunting that forest approached Kassapagotta wanting to stir him up, and recited these verses:

sn9.3:2.3.eng: It’s a waste of time to advise him, mendicant;
sn9.3:2.3.comm: Read bhikkhu here as vocative.

sn9.3:2.4.eng: he strikes me as an idiot.

sn9.3:4.1.eng: Even if you lit ten lamps

sn9.3:4.2.eng: and brought them to him, Kassapa,

sn9.3:4.4.eng: for he has no eyes to see.”

sn9.3:5.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā kassapagotto tāya devatāya saṃvejito saṃvegamāpādīti.
sn9.3:5.1.eng: Impelled by that deity, Venerable Kassapagotta was struck with a sense of urgency.

sn9.4:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ sambahulā bhikkhū kosalesu viharanti aññatarasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe.
sn9.4:1.1.eng: At one time several mendicants were staying in the land of the Kosalans in a certain forest grove.

sn9.4:1.2.pli: Atha kho te bhikkhū vassaṃvuṭṭhā temāsaccayena cārikaṃ pakkamiṃsu.
sn9.4:1.2.eng: Then after completing the three months of the rainy season residence, those mendicants set out wandering.

sn9.4:1.3.pli: Atha kho yā tasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe adhivatthā devatā te bhikkhū apassantī paridevamānā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
sn9.4:1.3.eng: Not seeing those mendicants, the deity haunting that forest cried. And on that occasion they spoke this verse:

sn9.4:2.1.comm: The idiom viya me khāyati (“seems to me”) is used for suppositions, so it must refer to the presumed dissatisfaction of the mendicants, rather than the disappointment of the deity.

sn9.4:2.3.eng: They were so learned, such brilliant speakers!

sn9.4:2.4.eng: Where have these disciples of Gotama gone?”

sn9.4:3.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, aññatarā devatā taṃ devataṃ gāthāya paccabhāsi:
sn9.4:3.1.eng: When they had spoken, another deity replied with this verse:

sn9.4:4.1.eng: “They’ve gone to Magadha, they’ve gone to Kosala,

sn9.4:4.2.eng: and some are in the Vajjian lands.

sn9.4:4.3.eng: Like deer that wander free of ties,

sn9.4:4.4.eng: the mendicants live with no abode.”
sn9.4:4.4.comm: A Brahmanical renunciate is said to wander “without fire or abode” (anagniraniketa, Manusmṛti 6.25, 6.43).

sn9.5:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā ānando kosalesu viharati aññatarasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe.
sn9.5:1.1.eng: At one time Venerable Ānanda was staying in the land of the Kosalans in a certain forest grove.

sn9.5:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā ānando ativelaṃ gihisaññattibahulo viharati.
sn9.5:1.2.eng: Now at that time Ānanda was spending too much time persuading lay people.
sn9.5:1.2.comm: The word “persuasion” (saññatti) is used in the context of discussions with skeptical non-Buddhists (eg. MN 60:8.5).

sn9.5:1.3.pli: Atha kho yā tasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe adhivatthā devatā āyasmato ānandassa anukampikā atthakāmā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ saṃvejetukāmā yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn9.5:1.3.eng: Then the deity haunting that forest had sympathy for Ānanda, wanting what’s best for him. So they approached him wanting to stir him up, and recited these verses:
sn9.5:1.3.comm: The same verse is spoken by a certain Vajjiputta (“Vajjian”) at Thag 1.119. The Pali commentary says this occurred shortly after the Buddha’s passing. Ānanda, still only a stream-enterer, was striving for arahantship before the First Council, but got caught up in consoling the distraught layfolk. The Mūlasarvāstivāda Vinaya agrees, adding that Vajjiputta was Ānanda’s attendant at the time. Following the exhortation, Ānanda meditated till late at night, then mindfully lay down to rest. When his feet were lifted off the floor, but his head not yet on his pillow, he became awakened (Rockhill, The Life of the Buddha, p. 155). The Pali Vinaya recounts the same events, but does not mention this verse (Kd 21:1.6.1).

sn9.5:2.1.eng: “You’ve left for the jungle, the root of a tree,

sn9.5:2.2.eng: having laid extinguishment in your heart.
sn9.5:2.2.comm: Both Bodhi here and Norman in the parallel in Elders Verses (Thag 1.119:1.2) read osiya (“having laid”), which agrees with the commentarial gloss.

sn9.5:2.4.eng: What use is this hullabaloo to you?”

sn9.5:3.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando tāya devatāya saṃvejito saṃvegamāpādīti.
sn9.5:3.1.eng: Impelled by that deity, Venerable Ānanda was struck with a sense of urgency.

sn9.6:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā anuruddho kosalesu viharati aññatarasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe.
sn9.6:1.1.eng: At one time Venerable Anuruddha was staying in the land of the Kosalans in a certain forest grove.

sn9.6:1.2.pli: Atha kho aññatarā tāvatiṃsakāyikā devatā jālinī nāma āyasmato anuruddhassa purāṇadutiyikā yenāyasmā anuruddho tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ anuruddhaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn9.6:1.2.eng: Then a certain deity of the company of the thirty-three named Penelope had been Anuruddha’s partner in a former life. She went up to Anuruddha, and recited these verses:
sn9.6:1.2.comm: Penelope (jālinī) means “weaver”, and is used as a term for the craving that binds beings in transmigration (eg. AN 4.199). Compare tantrāyī at Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 14.2.2.22.

sn9.6:2.3.eng: among the gods of the thirty-three,

sn9.6:2.5.eng: At the fore of a retinue

sn9.6:3.1.eng: “Divine maidens are in a sorry state,

sn9.6:3.3.eng: And those beings too are in a sorry state,

sn9.6:3.4.eng: who are attached to divine maidens.”
sn9.6:3.4.comm: Per Bodhi”s Connected Discourses, adopt reading devakaññābhisattikā found in a Sinhala-script manuscript cited in the PTS edition.

sn9.6:4.2.eng: who don’t see the Garden of Delight!

sn9.6:4.3.eng: It’s the abode of lordly gods,

sn9.6:5.2.eng: the saying of the perfected ones:

sn9.6:5.4.eng: their nature is to rise and fall;

sn9.6:6.1.eng: O Penelope, weaver of the web—

sn9.6:6.2.eng: there are no more abodes for me in the host of gods.

sn9.6:6.4.eng: now there’ll be no more future lives.”

sn9.7:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā nāgadatto kosalesu viharati aññatarasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe.
sn9.7:1.1.eng: At one time Venerable Nāgadatta was staying in the land of the Kosalans in a certain forest grove.
sn9.7:1.1.comm: This Nāgadatta is not mentioned elsewhere. His names suggests his parents had made an offering to dragon-spirits for a child, thus he is “Nāga-given”; cf. Devadatta, Brahmadatta, etc.

sn9.7:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā nāgadatto atikālena gāmaṃ pavisati, atidivā paṭikkamati.
sn9.7:1.2.eng: Now at that time Venerable Nāgadatta had been entering the village too early and returning late in the day.

sn9.7:1.3.pli: Atha kho yā tasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe adhivatthā devatā āyasmato nāgadattassa anukampikā atthakāmā āyasmantaṃ nāgadattaṃ saṃvejetukāmā yenāyasmā nāgadatto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ nāgadattaṃ gāthāhi ajjhabhāsi:
sn9.7:1.3.eng: Then the deity haunting that forest had sympathy for Nāgadatta, wanting what’s best for him. So they approached him wanting to stir him up, and recited these verses:

sn9.7:2.1.comm: For this verse, follow readings in Bodhi, Connected Discourses.

sn9.7:2.2.eng: and returning too late in the day,

sn9.7:3.1.eng: I’m afraid for Nāgadatta; he’s reckless,

sn9.7:3.3.eng: May he not come under the King of Death’s power,

sn9.7:3.4.eng: under the sway of the terminator!”

sn9.7:4.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā nāgadatto tāya devatāya saṃvejito saṃvegamāpādīti.
sn9.7:4.1.eng: Impelled by that deity, Venerable Nāgadatta was struck with a sense of urgency.

sn9.8:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ aññataro bhikkhu kosalesu viharati aññatarasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe.
sn9.8:1.1.eng: At one time one of the monks was staying in the land of the Kosalans in a certain forest grove.

sn9.8:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena so bhikkhu aññatarasmiṃ kule ativelaṃ ajjhogāḷhappatto viharati.
sn9.8:1.2.eng: Now at that time that monk had become too closely involved in the affairs of a certain family.

sn9.8:1.3.pli: Atha kho yā tasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe adhivatthā devatā tassa bhikkhuno anukampikā atthakāmā taṃ bhikkhuṃ saṃvejetukāmā yā tasmiṃ kule kulagharaṇī, tassā vaṇṇaṃ abhinimminitvā yena so bhikkhu tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā taṃ bhikkhuṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn9.8:1.3.eng: The deity haunting that forest had sympathy for that monk, wanting what’s best for him. So, wanting to stir him up, they manifested in the appearance of the mistress of that family, approached the monk, and addressed him in verse:

sn9.8:2.2.comm: For sabhā as a gathering-place for (disreputable) travellers, see Manu 9.264.

sn9.8:2.4.eng: what’s going on between you and me.”

sn9.8:3.1.comm: For the unique paccūhā see Sanskrit prativyūha, “an army arrayed against an enemy” or else “echo, reverberation”. It calls back to the previous line, “between you and me”.

sn9.8:3.2.eng: that a fervent ascetic must endure.

sn9.8:3.3.eng: They ought not be dismayed by that,

sn9.8:3.4.eng: for that’s not what defiles you.

sn9.8:4.1.eng: If you’re startled by every little sound,

sn9.8:4.2.eng: like a wind-deer in the wood,
sn9.8:4.2.comm: According to Haṁsadeva’s 13th century Mṛgapakṣiśāstra, the “wind-deer” (vātamiga, Sanskrit vātamṛga) is fast, skilled at escaping weapons and vanishing from sight. Dwelling in deep forests, it is lean with long legs and branched antlers. It makes an appearance also in Ja 14 and Tha Ap 482.

sn9.9:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ aññataro vajjiputtako bhikkhu vesāliyaṃ viharati aññatarasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe.
sn9.9:1.1.eng: At one time a certain Vajjian mendicant was staying near Vesālī in a certain forest grove.

sn9.9:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena vesāliyaṃ vajjiputtako sabbaratticāro hoti.
sn9.9:1.2.eng: Now at that time the Vajjis were holding an all-night event in Vesālī.

sn9.9:1.3.pli: Atha kho so bhikkhu vesāliyā tūriyatāḷitavāditanigghosasaddaṃ sutvā paridevamāno tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
sn9.9:1.3.eng: Then that mendicant, complaining at the noise of musical instruments being beaten and played, on that occasion spoke this verse:

sn9.9:2.2.eng: like a log dumped in the forest.

sn9.9:3.1.pli: Atha kho yā tasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe adhivatthā devatā tassa bhikkhuno anukampikā atthakāmā taṃ bhikkhuṃ saṃvejetukāmā yena so bhikkhu tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā taṃ bhikkhuṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn9.9:3.1.eng: The deity haunting that forest had sympathy for that mendicant, and wanted what’s best for them. So they approached that mendicant wanting to stir them up, and addressed them in verse:

sn9.9:4.2.eng: like a log dumped in the forest.

sn9.9:4.3.eng: Lots of people are jealous of you,

sn9.9:4.4.eng: like beings in hell of those going to heaven.”

sn9.9:5.1.pli: Atha kho so bhikkhu tāya devatāya saṃvejito saṃvegamāpādīti.
sn9.9:5.1.eng: Impelled by that deity, that mendicant was struck with a sense of urgency.
